metadata.title: Pressure Pulsing for Better Espresso | by Robert McKeon Aloe | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: Five years ago, I fell in love with lever espresso machines. They were capable of pressure profiling just like semiautomatic machines but without the cost. The main caveat: lever machines require an…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: I see on the bottom using my camera
extraction yield is determined using a digital refractometer (Atago)
Coffee Solubility in Espresso: An Initial Study
Espresso Simulation: First Steps in Computer Models
The Tale of the Stolen Espresso Machine

all_paragraphs: Five years ago, I fell in love with lever espresso machines. They were capable of pressure profiling just like semiautomatic machines but without the cost. The main caveat: lever machines require an artistry. Over time, I adjusted and learned how to make amazing espresso. I also bought a few more lever machines and lost a desire to buy the more expensive pressure profiling machines considering that pressure profiling was a standard feature for lever machines. I still read up on these new machines, and I found an interesting idea: pressure pulsing.

Regular espresso machines found at most coffee shops apply a constant amount of pressure (ideally 9 bars) to the hot water (ideally 90C) to make espresso. More advanced machines give a few intervals to tweak the pressure. Even better, you can do pre-infusion with very low pressure similar to a lever machine, and in this way, one can pressure profile a shot.

Pressure profiling involves modifying the pressure throughout the shot. You can start at a low pressure and end at a high pressure; you can start at a high pressure and end at a low pressure. Both give the shot different tastes.

The recent advancements of the decade have made PID controlled temperature and pressure accessible to the masses at least in coffee shops. These machines have reduced all the artistry to a science as each shot can be reproduced in terms of water temperature, pressure, and volume every time.

I recently read about the three phases of espresso, and I saw an interesting paragraph: “This became the foundation of Simonelli Group’s Pulse Jet technology, used in the Aurelia Wave espresso machine. For each of the three stages of espresso extraction, baristas can choose different flow rates that are pulsed through the puck.”
So I looked up the Aurelia Wave, but little information is available about how the pulsing works. The secrecy is probably on purpose, but I had a bright idea: I could try pulsing on a manual machine.
I had been using my Pavoni more often so I tried it on a staccato shot. It took longer to pull, but the result was amazing. It resulted in the best shot in my life up until this point.

André Eiermann had done some tests with the Aurelia Wave, and he didn’t find a TDS difference, but he did notice a taste difference. I wonder if measuring TDS at multiple points in volume extracted would show a bigger difference amongst the machine settings. I don’t think his experiments were as thorough as they could have been, but they were definitely a good start. There were a lot of variables he was trying to test, and prioritizing experiments is a lot of trial, error, and intuition.

Theoretically, pressure pulsing is similar to doing pre-infusion in the middle of the shot, multiple times. As such, one would expect the same or higher extraction in a given output volume based on what’s known about pre-infusion. Generally, using pre-infusion, espresso shots have higher extraction than without. The Aurelia Wave does do jet-pulsing during pre-infusion, but I have not tried that on a manual lever machine.
For a lever machine, we have a range of options. These instructions assume something like la Pavoni or Kim Express or Flair:

Pulse frequency and duration are the main variables. Currently, getting the pulses to provide a near steady stream of coffee is seems to be important. A lot of how I pulsed was based on sight during the shot, and using pulsing to get dark coffee to come out. The side-effect is less crema.

My intention was to try different method of pulsing with different durations. The problem is that with a lever machine, I pull more artisan shots where I’m adjusting based on what I see on the bottom using my camera. A Decent Espresso machine like the DE1Pro would have helped control more variables, but one thing I think that is inherent to pulsing on a lever machine is the feedback between visually seeing the bottomless portafilter and the barista making real-time adjustments.

To collect data, I tried to alternate which shots I would pressure pulse and which shots I would pull regular pressure shots. Regular pressure shots still had pre-infusion and bloom as pulsing applied only during infusion. I also pull most of my shots as staccato espresso shots because they taste better and have a higher extraction rate. Over time, I accumulated a lot of data, and then I pulled from this data a set of data points where the machine, coffee beans, and weights were the same for a regular pressure shot and a pressure pulsed shot.

I ended up with 17 data pairs, which is not enough for statistical significance. However, they work well for a qualitative examination. The difficulty in building up a statistically large enough set means that I have to make more than 30 pairs of shots which is difficult when I have other experiments going on as well as dialing in new coffee roasts. On top of that, I found pressure pulsing improved my shots, so to not do it, I knew I wasn’t pulling the best shots I could. That being said, I reduced my data to this below.

The two main metrics I used to compare were Extraction Yield and Final Score. Extraction yield is determined by how much coffee was extracted from the puck into the cup, and extraction yield is determined using a digital refractometer (Atago) to measure the Total Dissolved Solids (TDS). All 17 pairs have Final Score metrics, but only 9 data pairs have TDS metrics as I started collecting TDS measurements after I started collecting these paired data points.

Final score is the average of a scorecard of 7 metrics (Sharp, Rich, Syrup, Sweet, Sour, Bitter, and Aftertaste). These scores were subjective, of course, but they were calibrated to my tastes and helped me improve my shots. There is some variation in the scores. My aim was to be consistent for each metric, but some times the granularity was difficult.

First, looking at extraction yield, pressure pulsing was the same or better than regular shots in most cases. This chart shows the regular pressure extraction on the x-axis and the corresponding pressure pulsed extraction on the y-axis.

When looking at Final Score, the trend is similar, but there are more cases where pulsing does not help. However, this goes back to a thesis that pulsing will provide the same or better, never worse extraction because of its similarity to pre-infusion.

Here is an overall summary with some averages. I can’t make the argument that the distributions are statistically significant, but they have been interesting enough that I’ve used pressure pulsing in all of my shots since. I should also note that because I don’t pull non-Staccato shots often, I’m not exactly sure on the impact. From the non-Staccato shots I’ve pulled with and without pressure pulsing, I haven’t noticed as big of a difference in taste. What I suspect one is getting a higher extraction at the beginning of the shot, but I don’t have data to back that claim. I’ve also been using a longer pre-infusion more recently which has been an added variable.

I had a few other items I wanted to explore. I have currently added the number of pulses along with the timing for pre-infusion, bloom, and infusion to my data sheet. Hopefully this will give me some deeper insight to pressure pulsing. Obviously, if I had a pressure gauge or a DE1Pro, I could better control and measure the pulses and the pressure spike at each pulse. In the meantime, here is my list of experiments I have thought of while investigating pressure pulsing:

In conclusion, current evidence points towards pressure pulsing (including jet-pulsing) is better than constant pressure. The best part about pressure pulsing for manual machines, is that it is an easy method to apply and adapt to one’s own use; it doesn’t require an additional hardware.
P.S. For the Aurelia Wave, I hope someone examines performance differences of jet-pulsing at the 1:1 input/output ratio because my experiments have shown extraction is greatly affected by pulsing.
If you like, follow me on Twitter and YouTube where I post videos of espresso shots on different machines and espresso related stuff. You can also find me on LinkedIn.

I’m in love with my Wife, my Kids, Espresso, Data Science, tomatoes, cooking, engineering, talking, family, Paris, and Italy, not necessarily in that order.
